text: - [Narrator] Hello, everyone.
Today, I'm going to demonstrate

how Amazon Detective supports
investigating threats

detected by Amazon GuardDuty
Elastic Container Service
ECS Runtime Monitoring.

Amazon Detective makes it
easier to analyze, investigate,

and quickly identify the root
cause of security findings
or suspicious activities.
GuardDuty is a threat detection service

that continuously monitors
your AWS environment

for malicious activity
and unauthorized access.
GuardDuty now supports threat detection
for runtime events in Amazon ECS,

including serverless
workloads on AWS Fargate.

With Detective
investigations for GuardDuty
ECS Runtime monitoring capability,

security analysts can use the
new runtime threat detections

from GuardDuty and the
investigative capabilities
from Detective to improve detection
and response for potential threats
to their container workloads.
Now, I will switch over to the AWS console
for a brief demonstration.
From the AWS console, search for GuardDuty
and click on GuardDuty.
From the GuardDuty landing page,
click on Runtime Monitoring
from the Protection Plans dropdown.

Click on Edit to configure
runtime monitoring
if it is not enabled.

For this demo, Runtime Monitoring
has already been enabled.
Then click on Findings.

Let's examine a finding
related to Amazon ECS runtime.
Here, I can filter by resource type.
Check ECSCluster Box and click on Apply.

Then we can see a list of
GuardDuty ECS runtime findings.

We can take a look at the
DefenseEvationRuntime finding.

We are going to be provided
with a bit more context.
Click on the Info here
to see the full description of the finding
and the remediation recommendations.
Then you have the overview information

about the severity, region,
and additional details,

resource affected which
shows the resource type,

the ECS cluster details,
which gives the name, ARN,
and status of the cluster,
information on the task details,

container details, which
shows the ID, name,
and image of the container,
tags information,

as well as other runtime
details provided here.
Then scroll up
and click on Investigate with Detective.
Select GuardDuty Finding.
Now, we have been pivoted
into Amazon Detective from GuardDuty.
From here, we can see the entities
related to the GuardDuty ECS finding,
which include the account,

the specific details
on the container image,
the ECS task details,
and the ECS cluster details.

Let's browse into the ECS
container cluster here
and see the related information.

So you have the overview
details about the resource,
the type, the ARN, the scope time,
which reflects the first and last times
when the finding was observed.

You can also edit the
scope time as you wish.
Then we have the finding groups.

Finding groups enable you to
examine multiple activities
as they relate to a single security event.
Then we have the findings
associated with this resource.
The findings listed in the table

involve the entity that
this profile focuses on.
They occurred either within the scope time

or within a short time before
or after the scope time.
For each findings,
the list shows the finding title,
the description,
and the first and last time
this finding activity was observed,
including the finding severity.

In this video, we explored
how Amazon Detective
can help support investigating threats
detected by Amazon GuardDuty

Elastic Container Service
Runtime Monitoring.

You can try Amazon Detective
at no additional charge
with a 30-day free trial.
To learn more and get started,
check out the link in the description.
